'''Paul Lamb''' (born 9 July 1955, [[Blyth, Northumberland|Blyth]], [[Northumberland]], [[England]])<ref name="We7">{{cite web|url=http://www.we7.com/#/artist/Paul-Lamb--The-King-Snakes/bio!artistId=10016 |title=Free Music Online | blinkbox music |publisher=We7.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}}</ref><ref name="Nichol">{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/entertainment-in-newcastle/music/2012/09/07/what-s-on-latest-north-east-roots-music-news-72703-31789029/ |title=What's On: Latest North East roots music news |publisher=Chronicle Live |date=2012-09-07 |accessdate=2014-01-28}}</ref> is a [[British people|British]] [[blues]] [[harmonica]] player and [[bandleader]]. He has had a four decade long career as a blues harmonicist and bandleader, with [[fan (person)|fans]] around the world.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Bruce Eder |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/paul-lamb-mn0000749410/biography |title=Paul Lamb | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}}</ref>

==Biography==
Lamb started playing the harmonica during his childhood, inspired by [[Sonny Terry]], and he was fortunate to meet and collaborate with him after beginning to perform in [[nightclub|clubs]] by the age of fifteen.<ref name="AMG"/> Lamb played only [[acoustic music|acoustic]] blues until about 1980.<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 133
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> Lamb also played alongside his heroes such as [[Buddy Guy]], [[Junior Wells]], and [[Brownie McGhee]].<ref name="AMG"/> He formed the Blues Burglars with guitarist Johnny Whitehill in the early 1980s, a formation that eventually became Paul Lamb & the King Snakes. They released an eponymous album with [[Ace Records (UK)|Ace Records]] in 1990, followed by several others, each building both Lamb's personal reputation as a harmonica player and the band's prestige.<ref name="AMG"/> He was awarded with the British Blues Connection's annual award for the best local harmonica player several years in a row whilst the King Snakes frequently took the title as best band.<ref name="russell"/><ref name="Larkin">Larkin, Colin (1998) ''The Virgin Encyclopedia of Blues'', Virgin Books, ISBN 978-0753502266, p. 219</ref>

As a consequence, his own harmonica skills have been in demand, and he had a [[hit record|hit]] in 1994 in the [[UK Singles Chart]] with the track, "Harmonica Man" (under the [[pseudonym]] of '''Bravado''') with [[Pete Waterman]].<ref name="Nichol" /><ref name="Larkin" /><ref name="British Hit Singles & Albums">{{cite book
| first= David
| last= Roberts
| year= 2006
| title= British Hit Singles & Albums
| edition= 19th
| publisher= Guinness World Records Limited 
| location= London
| isbn= 1-904994-10-5
| page= 76}}</ref><ref name="Lamb"/> Lamb has also worked with [[Mark Knopfler]], [[The Who]], [[Rod Stewart]] and [[Jimmy Nail]], played on [[BBC]] and [[film]] [[soundtrack]]s, and various [[television commercials]] in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Lamb"/> 

Lamb was more recently inducted into the British Blues Awards Hall Of Fame.<ref name="Press">{{cite web|url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/leisure/music/1976679.print/ |title=Preview: Paul Lamb and The Kingsnakes; Neil Dalton and The Blue Aces, The Deep Blues Club, York, 22 January|publisher=Yorkpress.co.uk |date=2008-01-18 |accessdate=2014-01-28}}</ref><ref name="Lamb">[http://www.paullamb.com/bios/paul_bio.htm ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}}</ref> ''[[Blues & Rhythm]]'' [[magazine]] described his band as "lazily cocksure and coolly aggressive".<ref name="We7"/>

In 2011 he recorded a session for [[Paul Jones (singer)|Paul Jones]]' [[BBC Radio 2]] show.<ref name="BBC">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00xgnww |title=BBC Radio 2 - Paul Jones, 24/01/2011 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-01-24 |accessdate=2014-01-28}}</ref>

Members of the King Snakes band have included singer/guitarists Johnny Dickinson and Chad Strentz, bassists Jim Mercer, Dave Stevens, and Rod Demick, drummers Mike Thorne, Martin Deegan, Alan Savage, Daniel Strittmatter, and Sonny Below, and Paul's son Ryan on lead guitar.<ref name="Nichol" /><ref name="Rhodes">Rhodes, Graham (2008) "[http://www.chesterchronicle.co.uk/entertainment-chester/news-reviews/2008/10/05/review-paul-lamb-the-kingsnakes-in-warrington-59067-21973615/ Review: Paul Lamb & The Kingsnakes in Warrington]", ''[[Chester Chronicle]]'', 5 October 2008, retrieved 6 October 2012</ref>

==Discography==
*''Paul Lamb & the King Snakes'' (1990)
*''Fine Condition'' (1995)
*''She's a Killer'' (1996)
*''Shifting into Gear'' (1997)
*''John Henry Jumps In'' (1998)
*''The Blue Album'' (1999)
*''Blues Burglars Whoopin''' (1999)
*''Take Your Time and Get It Right'' (2000)
*''Live at the 100 Club'' (2001)
*''I'm on a Roll'' (2005)
*''Slice of Lamb'' (2007)
*''Snakes and Ladders Live'' (2007)
*''[[Mind Games (Paul Lamb Album)|Mind Games]]'' (2010)
*''[[The Games People Play (Paul Lamb album)|The Games People Play]]'' (2012)
*''[[Hole In The Wall (Paul Lamb album)|Hole In the Wall]]'' (2014)
<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/paul-lamb-mn0000749410/discography |title=Paul Lamb | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}}</ref>
